values.description:
Adding opportunity to define server without input parameter, create request and asynchronous request to this server. We could use the ```msgs::Empty``` for not having to modify the wire format when sending a service request.

There are three new examples with new feature.

Adding tests and integration tests.

values.description:
Not all the service requests require a response. We'd add some logic for removing the service request handler after sending the request, instead of waiting for the response. We could use the msgs::Empty for not having to modify the wire format when sending a service request. We'd create a new Request function in the Node class with only one parameter (the input parameter).

Two examples are included SrvProviderOneway and RequesterOneway.

Integration tests are also added.
values.title: Service requests without response

summary.raw:
Not all the service requests require a response. We'd add some logic for removing the service request handler after sending the request, instead of waiting for the response. We could use the msgs::Empty for not having to modify the wire format when sending a service request. We'd create a new Request function in the Node class with only one parameter (the input parameter).

Two examples are included SrvProviderOneway and RequesterOneway.

Integration tests are also added.
summary.html:
Not all the service requests require a response. We'd add some logic for removing the service request handler after sending the request, instead of waiting for the response. We could use the msgs::Empty for not having to modify the wire format when sending a service request. We'd create a new Request function in the Node class with only one parameter (the input parameter).

Two examples are included SrvProviderOneway and RequesterOneway.

Integration tests are also added.

values.description:
The new method ```bool Node::WaitForSubscribers(const std::string &_topic, const int _timeout = -1);``` is added. New classes ```TopicWatcher```, ```TopicWatcherPrivate```, ```TopicWatcherStorage``` were added to provide the opportunity to use this function.

In the ```NodeShared``` class there is  ```TopicWatcherStorage```. The data is a map where the keys are topics, the values are another map, where the key is nuuid, the value is shared_ptr<TopicWatcher>.

We could check ```NodeShared::localSubscriptions``` and ```NodeShared::remoteSubscribers``` first. Then if there is no subscriptions we create a topic watcher and call ```wait```.
values.title: Issue_47: Wait for subscribers

summary.raw:
The new method ```bool Node::WaitForSubscribers(const std::string &_topic, const int _timeout = -1);``` is added. New classes ```TopicWatcher```, ```TopicWatcherPrivate```, ```TopicWatcherStorage``` were added to provide the opportunity to use this function.

In the ```NodeShared``` class there is  ```TopicWatcherStorage```. The data is a map where the keys are topics, the values are another map, where the key is nuuid, the value is shared_ptr<TopicWatcher>.

We could check ```NodeShared::localSubscriptions``` and ```NodeShared::remoteSubscribers``` first. Then if there is no subscriptions we create a topic watcher and call ```wait```.
summary.html:
The new method bool Node::WaitForSubscribers(const std::string &_topic, const int _timeout = -1); is added. New classes TopicWatcher, TopicWatcherPrivate, TopicWatcherStorage were added to provide the opportunity to use this function.

In the NodeShared class there is TopicWatcherStorage. The data is a map where the keys are topics, the values are another map, where the key is nuuid, the value is shared_ptr<TopicWatcher>.

We could check NodeShared::localSubscriptions and NodeShared::remoteSubscribers first. Then if there is no subscriptions we create a topic watcher and call wait.

See [issue #1976](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1976/) from the Gazebo issue tracker.

values.description:
* Avoid two underscores in symbols as it's reserved for compiler's internal use. 
Reference: http://www.doc.ic.ac.uk/lab/cplus/c++.rules/chap5.html

* I also removed the `IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE` from the private classes.


CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/147) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/150) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/285) :large_blue_circle: 
* [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/21/API_ABI_report/) :large_blue_circle:

values.description:
See issue #52. 

I just replaced the call `std::exit` with a `return`. We could raise an exception but this constructor is triggered in the `Node` constructor, which is highly used. Having to wrap the `Node` constructor every time you use with a `try/catch` looks really inconvenient to me but other suggestions are welcome.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/) :white_circle: 
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/) :white_circle: 
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/) :white_circle: 
* [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/) :white_circle:

values.description:
This pull request extends `ign service` for being able to request a service from the command line (issue #42).

* Compile the examples and run `responser` for registering the `/echo` service:

```
#!c++

caguero@bb8:~/workspace/ign-transport/example/build$ ./responser
```

* Example that requests the `/echo` service with data="Hello"

```
#!c++

ign service -s /echo --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: "Hello"'
```

Note about the implementation:

As described in issue #42, when we are inside `ign.cc::cmdServiceReq()`, we call `ignition::msgs::Factory::New` to create the request and response messages based on their string types. Within `ign.cc::cmdServiceReq()`, we don't have access to the real types, we only have the string types, so the Ignition Msgs factory is not able to cast the new messages to the specific protobuf types (e.g.: ignition::msgs::StringMsg). Instead, it returns a pointer to a generic `google::protobuf::message`. 

This is a problem when we call `Node::Request()` and also when we create the `ReqHandler` inside `Node::Request()`. There are a few places where we need the specific type and not a generic `google::protobuf::message`. The solution that I found was to create a template specialization for `ReqHandler` when `[Req=google::protobuf::message]` and `[Rep=google::protobuf::message]`. It duplicates a little bit of code but seems to work. Maybe @nkoenig has another idea but at least this is a working version.

Note: This feature was originally started by Nadya Ampilogova (@nampi), credit for her.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/163/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](Link URL) :large_orange_diamond: (Jenkins seems offline)
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/336/) :large_blue_circle: (Just a well known warning that only shows up on Jenkins).
values.title: Request a service from the command line

summary.raw:
This pull request extends `ign service` for being able to request a service from the command line (issue #42).

* Compile the examples and run `responser` for registering the `/echo` service:

```
#!c++

caguero@bb8:~/workspace/ign-transport/example/build$ ./responser
```

* Example that requests the `/echo` service with data="Hello"

```
#!c++

ign service -s /echo --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: "Hello"'
```

Note about the implementation:

As described in issue #42, when we are inside `ign.cc::cmdServiceReq()`, we call `ignition::msgs::Factory::New` to create the request and response messages based on their string types. Within `ign.cc::cmdServiceReq()`, we don't have access to the real types, we only have the string types, so the Ignition Msgs factory is not able to cast the new messages to the specific protobuf types (e.g.: ignition::msgs::StringMsg). Instead, it returns a pointer to a generic `google::protobuf::message`. 

This is a problem when we call `Node::Request()` and also when we create the `ReqHandler` inside `Node::Request()`. There are a few places where we need the specific type and not a generic `google::protobuf::message`. The solution that I found was to create a template specialization for `ReqHandler` when `[Req=google::protobuf::message]` and `[Rep=google::protobuf::message]`. It duplicates a little bit of code but seems to work. Maybe @nkoenig has another idea but at least this is a working version.

Note: This feature was originally started by Nadya Ampilogova (@nampi), credit for her.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/163/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](Link URL) :large_orange_diamond: (Jenkins seems offline)
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/336/) :large_blue_circle: (Just a well known warning that only shows up on Jenkins).
summary.html:
This pull request extends ign service for being able to request a service from the command line (issue #42).

  • Compile the examples and run responser for registering the /echo service:
caguero@bb8:~/workspace/ign-transport/example/build$ ./responser
  • Example that requests the /echo service with data="Hello"
ign service -s /echo --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 1000 --req 'data: "Hello"'

Note about the implementation:

As described in issue #42, when we are inside ign.cc::cmdServiceReq(), we call ignition::msgs::Factory::New to create the request and response messages based on their string types. Within ign.cc::cmdServiceReq(), we don't have access to the real types, we only have the string types, so the Ignition Msgs factory is not able to cast the new messages to the specific protobuf types (e.g.: ignition::msgs::StringMsg). Instead, it returns a pointer to a generic google::protobuf::message.

This is a problem when we call Node::Request() and also when we create the ReqHandler inside Node::Request(). There are a few places where we need the specific type and not a generic google::protobuf::message. The solution that I found was to create a template specialization for ReqHandler when [Req=google::protobuf::message] and [Rep=google::protobuf::message]. It duplicates a little bit of code but seems to work. Maybe @nkoenig has another idea but at least this is a working version.

Note: This feature was originally started by Nadya Ampilogova (@nampi), credit for her.

CI results:

  • Trusty :large_blue_circle:
  • Homebrew (Jenkins seems offline)
  • Windows :large_blue_circle: (Just a well known warning that only shows up on Jenkins).

values.description:
Should fix [this homebrew bug](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/issues/120#issuecomment-247629023).

Tested in a patch in [debian unstable](https://anonscm.debian.org/cgit/debian-science/packages/ignition-transport.git/tree/debian/patches/0002-fix-protobuf3.patch).

summary.raw:
Should fix [this homebrew bug](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/issues/120#issuecomment-247629023).

Tested in a patch in [debian unstable](https://anonscm.debian.org/cgit/debian-science/packages/ignition-transport.git/tree/debian/patches/0002-fix-protobuf3.patch).
summary.html:
Should fix this homebrew bug.

Tested in a patch in debian unstable.

values.description:
* First version done.

* Use unsigned long int

* SubscribeOptions unit test.

* Integration test.

* Changelog

* Tweaks* Addresses issue #2
* A new class has been created for dealing with the subscription options. You can now specify the number of messages per second that you want to receive.

Note: This feature was originally started by Amitoj Singh (@amtj), credit for him.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/165) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/179/) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/334/) :large_blue_circle: (just one known warning that only shows up in Jenkins)

values.description:
[console warnings](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/169/consoleFull) with protobuf3 (on homebrew):

~~~
[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/compiler/parser.cc:547]
 No syntax specified for the proto file: int.proto.
 Please use 'syntax = "proto2";' or 'syntax = "proto3";' to specify a syntax version.
 (Defaulted to proto2 syntax.)
[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/compiler/parser.cc:547]
 No syntax specified for the proto file: vector3d.proto.
 Please use 'syntax = "proto2";' or 'syntax = "proto3";' to specify a syntax version.
 (Defaulted to proto2 syntax.)
~~~

There's some [other compiler warnings too](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/169/warnings8Result/), but I'm not sure the best way to fix them yet.
values.title: add syntax = proto2 to proto files to suppress warnings

values.description:
This is the first part of a refactor that changes the way we publish messages.

In this pull request two new classes have been created: `AdvertiseMessageOptions` and `AdvertiseServiceOptions`. This will be used as an optional argument when calling  `node.Advertise(...)`.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/177/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Mac](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/184/) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/340/) :large_blue_circle:

values.description:
* Change the way we publish a message. Now, a `Node::Publisher` object will be created after `Node::Advertise`. That object will be used for publishing messages.

* Note that the `Node::Unadvertise()` has been removed. When the `Node::Publisher` object runs out of scope, the topic is unadvertised.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/180/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/187/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/344/) :large_blue_circle:
values.title: Publisher refactor (3/3)

• Change the way we publish a message. Now, a Node::Publisher object will be created after Node::Advertise. That object will be used for publishing messages.

  • Note that the Node::Unadvertise() has been removed. When the Node::Publisher object runs out of scope, the topic is unadvertised.

CI results:

  • Trusty :large_blue_circle:
  • Homebrew :large_blue_circle:
  • Windows :large_blue_circle:

values.title: Bump up version to 3.0.0 and update documentation

values.description:
This pull request adds support for a generic callback that allows to receive messages of any type. This is useful for implementing `ign topic --echo`, a bridge, or a similar use case where there's no prior knowledge about the types on the subscriber side.

The signature of the alternative callback function is:

```
#!c++

void cb(const google::protobuf::Message &_msg)
```

See the new `example/subscriber_generic.cc` for a minimal example.

Note that the subscriber won't be able to receive any custom message that only the publisher knows. In order to make a complete self describing message and make this scenario work, much more changes are required. This will probably be tackled in future pull requests.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/182/) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/189/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/359/) :large_blue_circle:
values.title: Generic callback

summary.raw:
This pull request adds support for a generic callback that allows to receive messages of any type. This is useful for implementing `ign topic --echo`, a bridge, or a similar use case where there's no prior knowledge about the types on the subscriber side.

The signature of the alternative callback function is:

```
#!c++

void cb(const google::protobuf::Message &_msg)
```

See the new `example/subscriber_generic.cc` for a minimal example.

Note that the subscriber won't be able to receive any custom message that only the publisher knows. In order to make a complete self describing message and make this scenario work, much more changes are required. This will probably be tackled in future pull requests.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/182/) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/189/) :large_blue_circle:

summary.html:
This pull request adds support for a generic callback that allows to receive messages of any type. This is useful for implementing ign topic --echo, a bridge, or a similar use case where there's no prior knowledge about the types on the subscriber side.

The signature of the alternative callback function is:

void cb(const google::protobuf::Message &_msg)

See the new example/subscriber_generic.cc for a minimal example.

Note that the subscriber won't be able to receive any custom message that only the publisher knows. In order to make a complete self describing message and make this scenario work, much more changes are required. This will probably be tackled in future pull requests.

CI results:

  • Trusty :large_blue_circle:
  • Homebrew :large_blue_circle:
  • Windows :large_blue_circle:

values.description:
Add `ign topic --echo` as a command line utility.

Example: 

* Compile the examples and run in one terminal:

```
#!c++

./publisher
```

* Type in a different terminal:


```
#!c++

ign topic -e -t /foo
```

The content of the messages published should be printed in the terminal.

~~**Note**: This pull request is built atop of pull request #188, which should be merged first. [Here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/branches/compare/echo%0Dgeneric_callback#diff)'s a better diff.~~

CI results:

* [Ubuntu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/186/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/190/) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/360/) :large_blue_circle:

  • Type in a different terminal:

values.title: Optional message information in the subscription callback.

summary.html:
This pull request adds support for an alternative callback signature during message subscription.

This is the regular callback:

void cb(const ignition::msgs::StringMsg &_msg)
{
  std::cout << "Msg: " << _msg.data() << std::endl << std::endl;
}

This is the new alternative callback:

void cb(const ignition::msgs::StringMsg &_msg,
        const ignition::transport::MessageInfo &_info)
{
  std::cout << "Topic: [" << _info.Topic() << "]" << std::endl;
  std::cout << _msg.DebugString() << std::endl;
}

Note that both callback signatures are supported. The new parameter of type MessageInfo provides some information about the message received. For now, the only information is the topic name but more fields can be added in the future. This feature can be handy when sharing the same callback among multiple topics.

CI results:

  • Ubuntu :large_blue_circle:
  • Homebrew :large_blue_circle:
  • Windows :large_blue_circle:
